references: New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. 2002. Biota Information System of New Mexico. New Mexico Department of Game and Fish electronic database, BISON. Version January 2002, Santa Fe, New Mexico. Http://nmnhp.unm.edu/bisonm/bisonquery.php.

Thompson, B. C., P. J. Crist, J. S. Prior-Magee, R. A. Deitner, D. L. Garber, and M. A. Hughes. 1996. Gap analysis of biological diversity conservation in New Mexico using geographic information systems Research Completion Report, New Mexico Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit, Las Cruces, NM.
Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
Cockrum, E. Lendell & Y. Petryszyn. 1992. Mammals of the Southwestern United States and Northwestern Mexico. Treasure Chest Publications, Inc. Tucson, Arizona. 192 p.
Cornely, J. E., and R. J. Baker. 1986. Neotoma mexicana. The American Society of Mammalogists, Mammalian Species No. 262: 1-7.
Fitzgerald, J.P., C. A. Meaney, and D. M. Armstrong. 1994. Mammals of Colorado. Denver Museum of Natural History and University Press of Colorado: Niwot, Colorado. 467 pp.
Frey, J. K. 2004. Taxonomy and distribution of the mammals of New Mexico: an annotated checklist Occasional Papers, Museum, Texas Tech University 240:1-32
Durrant, S.D. 1952. Mammals of Utah: taxonomy and distribution. University of Kansas, Museum of Natural History 6:1-549.
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
N. mexicana is found in grama, buffalograss, ponderosa pine, pinyon, juniper, Chihuahuan pine, Apache pine, bristlecone pine, limber pine, aspen, Douglas-fir, white fir, spruce-fir, Engelmann's spruce, western live oak, silverleaf and netleaf oaks, gray oak, emory oak, Gambel's oak, Toumey's oak, Great Basin sagebrush, winter-fat, alderleaf mountain-mahogany, ill-scented sumac, sedges, muhly, fescue, cottonwood, alder, willow, common juniper, chaparral beargrass, New Mexico muhly, green sotol, and wavyleaf oak (Cornely and Baker 1986, hoffmeister 1986, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000).  It in montane mixed coniferous forests, coniferous forest, montane shrublands, pinyon-juniper woodlands, oak woodland, interior chaparral, tundra, juniper savannah, and agricultural land (Hoffmeister 1986, Fitzgerald et al. 1994, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000).  N. mexicana should be found in virtually all New Mexico mountains and occurs in the Rincon Mountains of Arizona (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000, Cockrum 1960).  When the species occurs with N. albigula it takes the more mesic sites (Thompson et al. 1996).  N. mexicana is a food generalist (Hoffmeister 1986, Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It eats choke cherry, winter-fat, snowberry, currant, oak, rabbitbrush, sagebrush, juniper, ponderosa pine, skunkbrush, mountain-mahogany, and yucca (Cornely and Baker 1986, Fitzgerald et al. 1994). It is a rock dweller and usually nests in rocky slopes, rock outcrops, and cliffs (Cornely and Baker 1986, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2000). The elevational range in the southwest is 305-2,896m (Cockrum 1960, Hoffmeister 1986, Thompson et al. 1996). N. mexicana occurs in the mountains of eastern Arizona, as well as the Hualapai Mountains and Prescott National Forest (Hoffmeister 1986). It is found in southwestern, central, and southeastern Colorado (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). The species occurs across most of New Mexico except the Llano Estacado (Findley et al. 1975, Frey 2004). It is present only in southeastern Utah (Durrant 1952, Utah GAP 1997).
